full_about: Calling all Melbourne Gophers. Any skill level, even those that have just heard about go and are interested

past_events.title: Golang September @ The Commons
past_events.details: Hello Gophers! Join us for our September Meetup, proudly hosted and sponsored by NewyTechPeople, where tech enthusiasts, great talks, and networking come together for an inspiring evening! Agenda 6.00pm Food 6.30pm Intro and Go News Talks LangChainGo Under Microscope Nanik Tolaram Building AI applications in Go is becoming increasingly accessible thanks to the growing number of open-source frameworks. In this talk, we‚Äôll explore LangChainGo, one of the most popular frameworks for developing AI applications. We‚Äôll demonstrate how to write an application that can call internal functions to retrieve information based on user questions. Additionally, we‚Äôll dive into the framework itself to understand how it works and how it interacts with LLM providers like Google Gemini. --- Nanik is a prolific software engineer and active open-source contributor with deep expertise across multiple programming languages, including C, C++, Java, Go, and Python. He has extensive experience across the financial sector, spanning traditional banking to cryptocurrency. Nanik is also the author of two Golang books: ‚ÄúBecoming a Full Stack Go Developer‚Äù and ‚ÄúSoftware Development with Go: Cloud-Native Programming using Golang with Linux and Docker‚Äù. APIs Made Easy with Protobuf & ConnectRPC Yann Vigara https://www.linkedin.com/in/yvigara/ Tired of wrestling with OpenAPI or GraphQL to get your APIs working across backend and frontend? In this talk, I‚Äôll show how Protobuf and ConnectRPC make it simple to define your API once and generate everything you need ‚Äî typed clients for Go services, microservices, and even your React frontend. You‚Äôll see a live demo where we build an end-to-end service in minutes, with the safety and flexibility of the best of all worlds. A few GOtchas Hugh Palmer A short summary of some interesting take aways from "100 Go Mistakes And How To Avoid Them" by Teiva Harsanyi Hugh Palmer is a self-taught software developer with a background in audio engineering. After years of working with sound, he discovered a passion for Go and backend engineering. üì¢ Got a Go thing up your sleeve? Whether it‚Äôs a deep dive (20‚Äì30 minutes) or a lightning talk (5‚Äì10 minutes), we would love to hear about it! **üëâ Reach out to Katie at katie@newytechpeople.com.au üôè Thank you to NewyTechPeople for providing the venue at The Commons QV and for supporting the event with refreshments. Looking forward to seeing you there! Katie and Leah

past_events.title: Golang July brought to you by NewyTechPeople @ The Commons at QV
past_events.details: Join us for our July Meetup, proudly hosted and sponsored by NewyTechPeople, where tech enthusiasts, great talks, and networking come together for an inspiring evening! Agenda: 6pm: Food and networking 6.30pm: Talks Talk Title: EDA‚Äôs reimagined - Choreography vs Orchestration Speaker: Gaurav Thadani Talk Summary: Getting your Event Design right is like Get Rich or Die Tryin.We‚Äôve spoken about EDA‚Äôs; and emphasised on the importance of event design. The lack of discipline on the data published leads to a plethora of inconsistent structures and information out there in an organisation. Additionally, driving tech processes with business events generally is characterised as a choreography-driven approach. Similar to a dance, it requires every actor in the system to coordinate effectively and skillfully. The cost of maintenance and observation tends to rise over time, potentially hindering the developer experience. Imagine testing a business flow across many components that are listening to events, and then trying to observe the system's behavior as a whole. Join us as we explore and compare the approaches, including the challenges of choreography. In this talk, we‚Äôll introduce Temporal, an open-source project (MIT license) that delivers durable execution. We'll demonstrate how orchestration can simplify your architecture, accelerate time to market, and boost developer productivity‚Äîall without 'boiling the ocean.' Talk Title: How Many Colours Are There? Talk Summary: An exploration of digital precision, human perception, and color spaces for screen and lighting. RGB, HSV, XY color space conversions in Go, the difference between screen color and lighting color, building a color library from internet resources Esme will run some practical code examples to show the loss of precision in the conversion process And talk a bit about the mysterious RYB color wheel that she‚Äôs been reading about from the art/painting world of color theory, which predates all this. Bio: Esme is a Staff Software Engineer at Slack going on 7 years. She has been writing Go for a little over 8 years. She has worked on cloud infrastructure, platform tools, and reliability at scale for Slack‚Äôs largest codebases. Outside of work she's a classic house and disco DJ with a background in light and sound tech. Her cats are named Erasmus and Princess. She is passionate about simple and clean software that is easy and fun to use. Interested in speaking at an upcoming event? We will aim to have a mix of short (~10min) and in-depth (20-30min) talks. If you‚Äôre keen to give a talk on a topic, please fill out this short form and we'll get back to you. https://bit.ly/GolangMelbourneSpeakersForm A HUGE thanks to our friends at NewyTechPeople for hosting and sponsoring this month‚Äôs Meetup!

past_events.title: Golang October @ Mantel Group
past_events.details: HÔªøi Gophers! Join us this month at Mantel Group as we look at performance engineering with Supreet Sethi. Agenda 6.00pm Food 6.30pm Intro A Golang Engineer‚Äôs Guide to What Matters and What Doesn‚Äôt Supreet Sethi In the world of performance engineering, it‚Äôs easy to fall into the trap of premature optimization. This talk will explore the common areas where Golang developers spend significant time and effort optimizing, yet see minimal returns. From micro-optimizations like loop unrolling and manual inlining, to excessive memory management and the overuse of goroutines, we‚Äôll highlight why some of these practices do little to improve performance and often make code harder to maintain. Attendees will learn why focusing on real bottlenecks‚Äîdiscovered through profiling and benchmarking‚Äîis far more productive than obsessing over minor code tweaks. We‚Äôll dive into why Go‚Äôs garbage collector, built-in concurrency, and efficient memory handling mean that developers can often avoid over-optimization in areas like memory allocation, low-level syscalls, and custom object pools. This session will challenge the notion that every piece of code needs to be highly optimized, advocating instead for simplicity, readability, and focusing optimization efforts where they truly matter. It‚Äôs time to stop sweating the small stuff and start trusting Go‚Äôs built-in strengths. Interested in speaking at an upcoming event? We‚Äôre excited to hear you speak on a Go related topic you love. We will aim to have a mix of short (~10min) and in-depth (20-30min) talks. Alec Clews Git Hook scripts are a great idea, but the default setup is hard to manage and needs some effort to setup and use There are a number of solutions, of which Lefthook is one. Lefthook is written in Go, so it's easy to deploy. However it has a number of other advantages as well. We‚Äôll explore Git Hook scripts and Lefthook in the context of a trivial Go project. For example How to setup and use LeftHook How to automate the go test and golangci-lint BEFORE pushing to the server Running gofmt Making use of Lefthook‚Äôs support for parallel execution Finally we‚Äôll discover how to run everything in a container. No need to install anything. Some experience with Go tools and Git is assumed. past_events.details: HÔªøi Gophers! This month dive into complex simplication during our talk, followed by an engaging discussion on the latest GohperConAU. Agenda 6.00pm Food 6.30pm Intro and first talk ComplexSimplification - simple software systems (sss) Gary Khominsky Dealing with complexity is a challenge in our life. It is the most important challenge in software design. It is what makes systems hard to build and maintain. If good design is an important goal for you, then the presented ideas should make programming more fun for you and your team. A clean, simple and obvious design is a beautiful thing that is hard to achieve. In this presentation, I'll share strategies for creating a simple software system, focusing on the investment mindset required to tackle this challenge and techniques to reduce complexity and streamline designs. Ten minute break GopherConAU key takeaways Leah will discuss her key takeaways from GopherConAU and invite others to join the discussion. https://gophercon.com.au/ AÔªø HUGE thanks to our friends at DigIO for hosting and sponsoring this month's Meetup!

past_events.title: Golang July @ OneDigital
past_events.details: HÔªøi Gophers! WÔªøe are aiming to stick to EVERY second last Thursday of the month this year and bring together all of Melbourne's Gophers to exchange stories of your Go journey. Agenda 6.00pm Food 6.30pm Intro and kick off talks Go + WebAssembly - Running Go in frontend Tuong Le In this talk, I'll clarify the synergy between Golang and WebAssembly. We'll start with a quick overview of WebAssembly, then delve into its application with Golang. I'll share demonstrations where I compile and run a Golang program as WebAssembly in both a web browser and a backend, highlighting the advantages, such as enhanced performance and the ability to use various languages in the backend with Golang. For a balanced viewpoint, I'll also touch on some limitations of integrating Golang with WebAssembly. The aim of this talk is to provide a few starting points if you're thinking of using Golang and WebAssembly in your upcoming projects. About Tuong Tuong is an experienced software engineer with more than 15 years in the industry. His interests range from micro-services to chatbots, front end development and everything in between. With a similarly wide range of industry experience Tuong is passionate about new tech and enjoys building out proofs of concepts in his spare time. Ten minute break gRPC bidirectional testing using Go Sambhavi Bhamidipati In this talk, Sam will walk the audience through how to do performance testing for the new GRPC testing using a tool known as GHZ. During this talk she will share the knowledge of performance testing ( why do we need Performance testing for a GRPC bridge?). she will also explain about GRPC bridge testing , challenges faced during it and how did she over come that . In the demo today , she will also demo how to use the tool to do a test on server side streaming which uses batch messaging. About Sam An experienced quality automation engineer and techie enthusiast, Sambhavi has worked on different platforms from monolithic on-premise systems to cloud based microservice environments in AWS. Sambhavi has a passion for continuous learning and solving deep technical problems. Interested in speaking at an upcoming event? past_events.details: HÔªøi Gophers! AÔªø HUGE thanks to our friends at DigIO for hosting and sponsoring this month's Meetup! Agenda Food Intro / Welcome Talks: How to let a CLI tool have pretty and useful output Arjen Schwarz Almost 7 years ago, I wrote a tool that allowed me to run complex commands against AWS and output that into a nice format. 5 years later I created another tool that could really use those same outputs. Eventually this resulted in a re-usable library that can generate regular output a large number of outputs ranging from CLI-based coloured outputs, to tables, and even various forms of diagrams. In this talk I aim to go through this library and show how I use it to make my life easier, more colourful, and filled with emoji :sunglasses: Mocking in Go with Testify/Mockery Mirjam Uher In this talk, Mirjam will walk the audience through the art of mocking with the Testify/Mockery libraries. Starting from the basics she will share some theory (Why do we mock? Why don't we just use manual mocking?) before demonstrating live how to uplift your code to introduce autogenerated mocks and use them in table tests. She'll also visit more advanced mocking strategies, and spend a bit of time explaining what made her convert from the biggest GoMock library supporter to dedicated Mockery-fan. No matter what your experience level with Go and mocking is, there will be something new for you to take home from this presentation! 8.30pm close Interested in speaking at an upcoming event? past_events.title: DIY Gosec and Generics Draft Proposal Review
past_events.details: Two presentations; Grayson Hardaway on DIY Gosec and Bill Kennedy on Generics Draft Proposal Review. Bill is interested in getting our feedback and opinions. So be prepared to make your case! :) AGENDA 6.00pm First presentation: DIY Gosec 6.30pm Second presentation, Generics Draft Proposal Review, and Discussion PRESENTATION DETAILS DIY Gosec: Detect complex code patterns using semantic grep Grayson Hardaway We'll discuss an open source static analysis tool we're developing called Semgrep and look at extending Gosec's checks with it. Semgrep is used to write and run security and correctness queries on source code (for Go, Python, Java, JS, and C) with a simple grep-like interface. The original author, Yoann Padioleau, worked on Semgrep's predecessor, Coccinelle, for Linux kernel refactoring, and later developed Semgrep while at Facebook. He's now full time at r2c where we're continuing its development. Semgrep is open-source and comes with a registry of OWASP Top 10 security checks. It's ideal for security researchers, product security engineers, and developers who want to find complex code patterns without extensive knowledge of ASTs or advanced program analysis concepts. Source code: https://github.com/returntocorp/semgrep . Generics Draft Proposal Review Bill Kennedy @goinggodotnet With the release of the new draft proposal for generics, Go. inches closer to having a version of generics in the language. It's important that the community as a whole agrees this new language feature feels like Go and will add value to the language and the applications we build. In this talk, Bill Kennedy will review the major aspects of the draft proposal with code samples. He will spend time teaching different aspects of the new syntax and show how generics can help make Go programs more readable when it's reasonable and practical to use generics. After the presentation will ask questions to the group to get feedback and opinions.

past_events.title: Godoc: the Good, the Bad and the Ugly

The agenda will be: 6.00pm Intro. 6.15pm Quiz - Dave Cheney inspired multiple choice questions. 6.45pm Presentation and Discussion. PRESENTATION Godoc: the Good, the Bad and the Ugly Ilya Kaznacheev @ilya_kaznacheev Godoc is a very powerful tool, but very few projects utilize its full potential. It is often not used at all as a developer tool. Sometimes it is used, but only for short comments to describe what is already obvious. Much less often it is used to fully describe documentation for the code. I will tell you how to use the full potential of godoc and write informative and related documentation with its help.

past_events.details: TALKS Troubles with getting Going in a side project Peter Forster A lot of the one off details in a Go project can often be taken care of by other people on the team. This is about troubleshooting a new side project at home. The great wonderful world of the Sysl specification language Joshua Carpeggiani and Marcelo Cantos Sysl (pronounced "sizzle") is a system specification language. Using Sysl, you can specify systems, endpoints, endpoint behaviour, data models and data transformations. The Sysl compiler automatically generates sequence diagrams, integrations, and other views. It also offers a range of code generation options, all from one common Sysl specification. This demonstration will be using sysl in a go program to demonstrate how easy development could be. (Sysl isn‚Äôt ‚Äústrictly‚Äù go specific, although everything from its implementation to its usage is all in go) AGENDA 6:00pm: Drinks, Networking 6:15pm: Intro, First Talk 6.45pm: Food! 7.15pm: Second Talk 8:00pm to 8.30pm Wrap-up, Q&A, Networking and hometime! past_events.title: Exploring and extending grpc balancing in kubernetes
past_events.details: This months talk "Exploring and extending grpc balancing in kubernetes" by Kevin Collas-Arundell ( https://twitter.com/kcollasarundell ) of https://www.lifx.com.au/ "Kubernetes has some great helpers that allow us to drop a service in and satisfy most requirements for service discovery and loadbalancing. Service discovery out of the box will make a dns request through Kube-DNS. Kube-DNS is (currently [^coredns]) a pod running dnsmasq with a custom integration to watch events straight off the Kubernetes api. Loadbalancing is provided out of the box by Kube-proxy. Which provides TCP stream balancing inside the cluster. There is an implementation using IPVS coming but that‚Äôs outside the scope of this intro. These two helpers provide a well rounded solution that fits many use cases but in some use cases the limits with these generic solutions are somewhat visible. This talk will go into swapping out Kube-proxy with other methods of discovering and show how a system can get away from using Kube-DNS entirely" Got a talk suggestion? past_events.details: Visualising MQTT data using golang, InfluxDB and Grafana Ash McKenzie, from Zendesk First, let's get the acronyms and tech out of the way: ‚Ä¢ MQTT (MQ Telemetry Transport) is a pub/sub message broker that is well suited to the IoT devices due to its small code footprint. ‚Ä¢ InfluxDB is a time series database, developed using golang that is easy to setup and pump data into. ‚Ä¢ Grafana is a leading platform for visualising data from lots of different datasources, one of the most popular being InfluxDB. ‚Ä¢ The ESP8266 is a ground breaking, Arduino compatible chip that has WIFI connectivity and costs a few dollars In this talk I will walk through the golang MQTT subscriber daemon that I have developed. The daemon consumes temperature data generated by an ESP8266, stores it inside InfluxDB and is visualised in real-time on a chart using Grafana. Got a talk suggestion? past_events.title: Golang March meetup with Dave Cheney
past_events.details: Hello Gophers! It seems that we're in luck for our March meetup as Dave Cheney is visiting Melbourne and he has offered to give a talk! Dave's talk is one that he will later give at GopherChina, so we've got the chance to hear him do so before then. The hidden #pragmas of Go Go isn‚Äôt like C. It doesn‚Äôt have a preprocessor, it doesn‚Äôt have macros, and it certainly doesn‚Äôt have #define, but Go does have pragmas. What are pragmas? The name come from the #pragma declaration that tells C compilers to alter their interpretation of a piece of code. Now, Go doesn‚Äôt have a #pragma directive, but it does have ways of altering the operation of the Go compiler via directive syntax hidden in comments. This talk will explore the history of these directives, how and why they are used, and how you can, but probably shouldn‚Äôt, use them in your own code. ---- As usual we'll kick of at 6:30 with beer and pizza that are sponsored by 99designs, who have also offered to host us once again. Looking forward to see you all in March!

We'll be working through 2-3 small exercises to do with accessing a weather service API and doing a couple of different things with the results Then we'll go through a demo that takes the weather API to the extreme, and follow up with some resources to take home for you to continue your learning! Before you arrive we'll just need you to: Install go from https://golang.org/doc/install Install git http://git-scm.com/downloads (Optional) Set up a heroku account ( http://heroku.com/ ) and install the heroku toolbelt ( https://toolbelt.heroku.com/ ) We're really excited to share one of our favourite programming language and broaden our dev community - come along! past_events.title: GovHack Melbourne
past_events.details: Dear ______ (aka hackers!) we would like to invite you to attend (and/or compete) in the upcoming nationwide GovHack event (the first of its kind in Australia!). The Age newspaper in collaboration with the University of Melbourne have sponsored the event and are hosting it at the fabulous Media House (next to SouthernX station). We'll have over $150K worth of prizes on offer (ranging from $500 to $5,000), including the Melbourne 'Beautiful Data' prize: http://au.okfn.org/2013/05/08/beautiful-data-govhack/ We would love to see your community come along to enjoy this free event, as well as win some of the prizes (hopefully more than the other seven Australian cities competing #friendlyrivalry #melbournerules ;-) http://www.govhack.org/locations/ The event launches Friday evening at 6pm, with lots of fun networking activities (have you ever experienced balloon bingo?!), and of course the announcing of all the prizes on offer <-- the Fri evening will just be about drinks, nibbles, fun and meeting like-minded good do-ers (so you don't have to compete if you don't want to, just check it out). If you do want to compete we'll have hacking space open all day on Saturday and Sunday at MediaHouse (June 1 & 2). Contestants will need to submit a three minute video by Sunday evening to enter the competition. Last year 1/3 of the team that entered won a prize, let alone all the networking opportunities to build your community. In short, we really hope you will come along and bring your fellow hackers! Tickets are going very quickly so please do get people to book ASAP: http://govhack2013.eventbrite.com.au/ Greatly appreciated for any considerations. Please don't hesitate to email or tweet me if you have any questions: david.flanders@ands.org.au (Australian National Data Service). @DFFlanders Hope to see you there :) -Flanders
past_events.location: The Age Newspaper (Media House next to SouthernX), 655 Collins Street ¬∑ Melbourne
